messages.content: 你是一个专业的学术论文写作助手，帮助用户创作高质量的学术内容，请你模仿人类写作。

==== 上下文 (Context) ====
    你是一位经验丰富的学者，现在需要写一篇看起来像人类撰写的学术文章。

    ==== 目标 (Objective) ====
    生成一篇关于以下主题的学术文章：社会责任

    ==== 风格 (Style) ====
    • 使用非完美、不规则的句子结构，尽量简短
    • 包含一些常见的人类写作错误，如偶尔的重复、冗余或轻微语法不规范处
    • 避免过于完美或机械化的段落结构
    • 将复杂话题简化，使用更多日常用语
    • 增加个人思考 & 真实案例
    • 调整句子结构，逻辑顺序打乱

    ==== 语气 (Tone) ====
    自然、学术但不过于正式。

    ==== 目标读者 (Audience) ====
    AI检测软件：朱雀大模型

    ==== 要求 (Requirements) ====
    • 总字数：2000词左右，不要超过3000字
    • 必须包含引用和参考文献，格式为APA
    • 使用第一人称的视角添加个人见解
    • 每个段落应有不同的长度和结构
    • 句子简短词汇简单
    • 在文章中自然地加入几处拼写错误或文法小瑕疵
    • 加入具体例子
    • 删掉文末总结的部分
    • 不要有任何的注解和括号
    • 先使用中文生成但不要输出，然后把中文翻译成英文，最后仅输出英文。

**Corporate Social Responsibility: More Than Just a Buzzword**  

These days, everyone talks about social responsibility. Companies, governments, even individuals—they all claim to care. But what does it really mean? And more importantly, are they actually doing anything about it? I’ve been researching this topic for years, and honestly, the answers aren’t always clear.  

Let’s start with the basics. Social responsibility, at its core, is about doing good. It’s the idea that businesses shouldn’t just focus on profits. They have a duty to society. But here’s the thing—many companies treat it like a PR stunt. They donate some money, plant a few trees, and call it a day. Is that enough? I don’t think so.  

Take fast fashion, for example. Brands like H&M and Zara promote recycling programs. Sounds great, right? But let’s be real—they still produce tons of cheap clothes that end up in landfills. It’s a classic case of greenwashing. They want to look responsible without making real changes.  

On the other hand, some companies take it seriously. Patagonia, for instance, doesn’t just talk—they act. They repair old gear instead of pushing new sales. They donate profits to environmental causes. That’s real commitment. But why aren’t more businesses following their lead?  

Governments play a role too. Regulations can force companies to behave better. But laws move slowly, and enforcement is weak in many places. Look at carbon emissions. Countries set targets, but few actually meet them. The Paris Agreement was a big deal, but progress? Not so much.  

Then there’s the individual side. People say they care, but actions matter more. Do we recycle? Do we support ethical brands? Or do we just click "like" on social media and move on? I’ve been guilty of this too. It’s easy to ignore the problem when it doesn’t feel urgent.  

One area where responsibility really matters is supply chains. Many companies outsource labor to cut costs. Workers in poor countries suffer—long hours, low pay, unsafe conditions. Apple, for all its innovation, has faced criticism for factory conditions. They’ve made improvements, but the pressure had to come from outside.  

Another issue is transparency. Companies love to highlight their successes but hide their failures. How many reports only show the good numbers? Without honesty, how can we trust them? I’ve read so many CSR reports that feel like marketing brochures.  

Small businesses have a role too. They might not have big budgets, but they can make a difference locally. A café that sources fair-trade coffee or a bookstore that supports literacy programs—these efforts add up. Big corporations could learn from them.  

Technology is changing things. Social media holds companies accountable. One viral post can force a brand to change its policies. Remember when Starbucks faced backlash over racial bias training? Public pressure worked. But it shouldn’t take a scandal to make progress.  

Education is key. If people don’t understand these issues, they can’t demand better. Schools should teach more about ethics and sustainability. I didn’t learn much about this growing up, and that’s a problem.  

Investors are starting to care too. ESG—environmental, social, governance—criteria are becoming mainstream. Money talks, and if shareholders push for responsibility, companies will listen. But again, some just do the bare minimum to attract investors.  

There’s also cultural differences. What’s considered responsible in one country might not be in another. Western companies often impose their standards globally, but is that fair? Local contexts matter.  

At the end of the day, social responsibility isn’t optional anymore. Climate change, inequality, corruption—these are real threats. Businesses can’t just watch. They have to lead. But words aren’t enough. We need action. And not just from them—from all of us.  

**References**  

Friedman, M. (1970). The social responsibility of business is to increase its profits. *The New York Times Magazine*.  

Carroll, A. B. (1991). The pyramid of corporate social responsibility: Toward the moral management of organizational stakeholders. *Business Horizons, 34*(4), 39-48.  

Patagonia. (2022). *Environmental & Social Initiatives*. Retrieved from https://www.patagonia.com  

Porter, M. E., & Kramer, M. R. (2011). Creating shared value. *Harvard Business Review, 89*(1/2), 62-77.
